Taylor Swift Says ‘Hey Stephen' to Colbert in Cute Backstage Video Ahead of ‘Late Show' Visit
Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-12-11 02:44:11

Swift last appeared on The Late Show With Stephen Colbert in 2021. By Katie Atkinson Executive Digital Director, West Coast Taylor Swift and Stephen Colbert made an adorable TikTok video together backstage at The Late Show ahead of the pop superstar's late-night visit on Wednesday night (Dec. 10) — and the duo had the perfect song for their soundtrack. The video begins with a close-up of Swift in a red lip and a fuzzy winter jacket vibing to the humming intro of her 2008 Fearless album cut “Hey Stephen.” When the camera pans out, we see that The Late Show With Stephen Colbert host is there too, and he even lip-syncs the first word of the song: “Yeah.” Swift then breaks her so-far straight face to give a big goofy smile and wave at the late-night host and mouth, “Hey, Stephen!” The jangly country-pop song was never released as a single, but it did crack the Billboard Hot 100, peaking at No. 94 the week Fearless debuted. Back in 2021, during a virtual Swift appearance on The Late Show, Colbert jokingly grilled the singer/songwriter about whether he was the inspiration behind the unrequited-love song. “Don't flatter yourself,” she quipped at the time, going on to joke that it was actually about author Stephen King. “He's amazing,” Swift said. “The Dark Tower series changed my life. Plus The Shining, The Stand. And don't even get me started on his short stories.” In fact, Swift has previously confirmed that the titular love interest was Stephen Barker Liles from country duo Love and Theft, who opened for her in 2008, even spelling out the name of his group in the Fearless liner notes as further proof. Swift returns to The Late Show for the first time since that 2021 appearance Wednesday night at 11:35 p.m. ET on CBS and streaming on Paramount+. Hey Stephen, I know looks can be deceiving, but @Taylor Swift is here. #Colbert #TaylorSwift Get weekly rundowns straight to your inbox A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Bill de Blasio's ex Nomiki Konst claims former mayor wanted kids with her before cheating scandal
Source: pagesix.com    Published: 2025-12-11 02:44:00

Bill de Blasio's ex Nomiki Konst said he wanted to have a child with her before he cheated on her with Arizona mayor Roxanna Valenzuela. Konst dropped the bombshell during her appearance on the YouTube show “Why Did They Break Up?”. The political commentator, 41, shared that she has Endometriosis and underwent six rounds of egg freezing. She said she brought this up with de Blasio, 64, and that he was not only “open” to the conversation about the possibility of having children with her, he actually asked her lots of questions about it. Advertisement “On that flight to California, we talked the entire time about the process and what it would be like, we just got pretty serious very quickly,” she recalled. Advertisement When host Touré asked her, “He wanted to have a child with you?,” she replied, “Yes.” But a source told Page Six that Konst and de Blasio weren't trying to have children together, despite her freezing her eggs. Sources dropped details to Page Six about the former New York City mayor's headline-making affair with Valenzuela, specifically, how it began. De Blasio and Valenzuela began seeing each other more than a month before he split from Konst, whom he dated for nearly a year. Advertisement Start your day with Page Six Daily. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want celebrity news as it breaks? The politicians first met for a business lunch in September, then the pair went back to his apartment to have sex hours later, a source told us. Two days later, the two had another tryst when the South Tucson mayor took him to volunteer at a soup kitchen. Advertisement De Blasio came clean to Konst about the affair while they were on a vacation in Greece when she was in the midst of a round of IVF for egg freezing, a source said. Still, a source close to Konst told us that she and de Blasio attempted to work it out. But we're told that on Nov. 4, she “learned he was still talking to Roxanna and [Roxanna] was coming to NYC [to see him] while they were walking into Zohran Mamdani's election night victory party.” De Blasio is still dating Valenzuela, 41, and tells Page Six that he “fell in love” with her. “I wish Nomiki well and I'm sorry for how our relationship ended,” he told us. “I fell in love with someone else and I should have told her sooner. I'm now in a wonderful relationship with Roxanna Valenzuela that we will continue to nurture and keep private.” De Blasio has two children with Chirlane McCray, who formerly identified as a lesbian. The pair separated in 2023 and do not intend to divorce.

Guy Fieri Stands His Ground on One Hotly Debated Cooking Question
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-12-11 01:36:07

Guy Fieri has never been shy about speaking his mind, but even longtime fans were surprised to learn there is one kitchen question that pushes him toward confrontation. In a recent video shared by the Food Network, Fieri responded to a series of rapid-fire culinary debates and stopped cold when asked whether cooks should ever use pre-minced garlic. “Okay, you want to fight?” he said in the Instagram clip. The exchange offered more than a joke. It revealed how fiercely the “Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives” host protects what he sees as the fundamentals of good cooking. The garlic debate served as the clearest example of his belief that technique matters and shortcuts undermine the heart of the craft. Fieri ran through several cooking questions in the video. According to the video, he said he does not wash chicken, and he told viewers not to add oil to boiling pasta water. He confirmed that he rinses rice before cooking it and explained that he maintains his cast-iron cookware with water and scraping instead of soap. Another question prompted an even more animated response. When asked if breaking spaghetti before boiling it was acceptable, Fieri paused and jokingly mimed a punch to show where he stood. The garlic question, though, drew the strongest reaction. Fieri did not offer a detailed explanation in the clip, but his tone made clear that he sees pre-minced garlic as a step too far from the integrity of fresh ingredients. His reaction echoed a long-running theme in his public cooking philosophy: flavor starts with technique, and technique starts with doing the work. The garlic moment came only days after Fieri gave another set of candid opinions in a separate Food Network holiday video. This time, he weighed in on holiday dinners and did not hesitate when asked what he considers the most overrated part of festive meals. “All the desserts. What is up with that?” he said, adding that hosts should focus on appetizers and the main course instead of offering elaborate sweets. In the same video, Fieri said he would rather guests arrive slightly late than early so he can finish cooking in peace. He also said he prefers artificial Christmas trees because they are easier to manage during the busy season. Fieri's comments resonated partly because they blended humor with conviction. Fans often celebrate his larger-than-life personality, but clips like these highlight the seriousness beneath the jokes. He may tease about “starting a fight,” yet the sentiment reflects his long-standing commitment to cooking with intention. For Fieri, flavor begins long before food hits the pan. It begins with the choices cooks make. And if one of those choices involves a jar of pre-minced garlic, he is ready to speak up every single time. The 35+ Best Gifts for Husbands, According to a Wife Who Has Bought All of Them
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-12-11 01:34:23

By Alexis Mikulski Ruiz If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, Rolling Stone may receive an affiliate commission. My husband loves me for a lot of reasons: my sparkling personality, my willingness to attend any (and all) EDM concerts, and my undying devotion to the Shrek franchise (just quoting his vows, not mine). But another reason is my gift-giving skills. And yes, I'll toot my own horn a little — I give a damn good gift. Ever since we met, he's told me that if gift-giving were a competitive sport, I'd win. Which says a lot, because I don't think anyone has ever complimented my athletic abilities. So if you're struggling to find the perfect gift for your husband this holiday season, or if he's the type of man who claims he “wants nothing” while secretly drooling over the latest tech, you've come to the right place. Over the course of my relationship with Mr. Alexis Mikulski Ruiz, I've bought more presents than I can count. Gifts for Christmas? Easy. Birthdays? Obviously. But also Arbor Day, the Fourth of July, and, of course, National Star Wars Day — I don't mess around, and I've had plenty of practice. This is all to say: when it comes to curating something your man will actually love, I am your girl. I've compiled a list of the best gifts for husbands this year — items I've personally tried, bought, and tested, ranging from cozy cashmere sweaters to movie screenplays and unique LED lighting gadgets. These are the kinds of presents he'll be genuinely psyched to find under the tree. Prices start as low as $20 and go up to a few hundred, so there's something for everyone in this guide. He's the love of your life; he deserves a little more than just another tie. Shop the best gifts for husbands in 2025 below. $48.00 If you married a Deadhead, congratulations — you're a Deadhead by default. Malbon just dropped an elevated collab with the band that looks like something you won't find in a dusty thrift bin. Get him the beanie and a matching vinyl and send that man “Truckin'” along. $75.00 This Leatherology wallet is sleek, high-quality, and monogrammable, so when he inevitably loses it at your next house party or dinner, everyone will know exactly who it belongs to. Honestly, throw in some Apple AirTags too. For safety. $92.50 Derby shoes are a must for the man in your life, and one of our favorites is by ECCO. Not only will they add a certain je ne sais quoi to his outfit, but they'll also make you look better by association. A win-win. $191.00 These are my husband's favorite sunglasses, and they can be your husband's too (aww, twins). They've survived ball games, beach days, and every time he pretends he's totally not napping during lunch with the in-laws. $128.00 Technically, my husband works for Mr. Bezos, but if you ask me, his true full-time career is “professional groomsman.” He doesn't leave for a wedding without this Halfday bag. It stores everything he needs and somehow keeps his suit wrinkle-free. $62.00 In our family, Acqua di Giò is the scent that keeps on giving. I gave it to my husband for the holidays in 2021, and he liked it so much he gifted it to all his groomsmen. Yes, it smells that good. It's the kind of cologne you spray on his pillow when he's out of town just to get another whiff. $88.50 $118.00 25% off Whether he's spinning all day on the green or accompanying you on weekend errands, this UNTUCKit hoodie will keep him comfortable and stylish. It's the perfect upgrade from that ratty old frat crewneck he refuses to retire, so you won't even roll your eyes when he inevitably says, “I don't wanna dress up today.” $150.00 Men sometimes need a little wardrobe nudge, and these Florsheim shoes deliver. As my husband puts it, “They're so comfortable I could walk the length of Manhattan in them.” A man of few words — but when it comes to a last-minute gift, his recommendation tells you everything you need to know. $75.00 $84.00 11% off It's time for him to ditch the ripped briefs and upgrade to these Bombas boxers. They're soft, supportive, and bonus, they look good on him and on you (for when you inevitably steal them). $298.00 Men want to feel pretty, too. And one of the fastest ways to make that happen is with a cashmere sweater. The first time my husband slipped into this magical fabric, he looked at me like he didn't know that level of comfort existed — and now yours can experience the same enlightenment. $90.00 If he dreamed of getting drafted after high school but ended up in a tech job instead, he can still look the part with something from Game 7. Founded by hockey GOAT Mark Messier, their gear for the NHL and NBA actually looks like elevated athleisure, not a cheap novelty. $138.00 These are my husband's go-to pants — whether we're flying across the country or he has a big presentation at the office. They feel like sweatpants but look like dress slacks, meaning he never has to choose between “office appropriate” and “what's going to get me written up again.” $75.00 If he's a golfer, a tennis enthusiast, or simply works a finance job (secure that bag), a classic white polo is always a good idea. Get him a few colors — future-you will thank present-you when he's getting dressed in the morning. $97.50 Every man needs at least one great set of sneakers. If he's tired of the same pairs every guy on the street owns, treat him to something different with these leather kicks from ECCO. They're an elevated basic for the guy who deserves more than the norm. $89.95 Men need Christmas pajamas, too. This set from L.L.Bean won't overheat him at night if he's the type who thrashes in his sleep, and he'll look adorable on your family Christmas card, whether you had to drag him to the photo shoot or not. $325.00 I got this watch for my husband for our wedding, and to this day, it's still his favorite timepiece. Nixon watches are less expensive than the big luxury brands, but honestly, the quality rivals the fanciest stuff on the market. When he opens it, he'll think you spent a fortune; no need to tell him otherwise. $98.00 For an upcoming trip to paradise, prep him with a themed trunk set. Fun, stylish, and a long-overdue replacement for the beat-up bathing costume he's been hoarding since the early 2000s. $195.00 A man wearing a bracelet instantly becomes hotter. I don't make the rules. This one from David Yurman is simple, subtle, and comes with a secure clasp (because if he can lose his keys, he can lose anything). $134.98 $149.99 10% off These LED lighting tiles were one of the first gifts I ever bought my husband back when I was still girlfriend-level. He used the original set for eight years. We recently upgraded, and while the custom shape has gotten classier, the quality's still A+. Hang them up, pair with your favorite playlist, and voilà — date night at home for the two of you. $399.00 $499.99 20% off The PlayStation 5 is a must for any gamer and absolutely what he's secretly hoping for this year — he just didn't want to look greedy for Santa Claus. Surprise him, and you might earn some blissful peace and quiet while he's yelling into a microphone with his boys in the other room. $99.99 Sure, this one's practical, but I'm guessing your husband still has the same phone case he got with his initial purchase. Upgrade him with this waterproof OtterBox. It'll protect his phone and your sanity from another trip to the Verizon store for a cracked screen. $499.00 If you've ever caught him glued to the screen during Black Mirror or Westworld, treat him to his own alternate reality with the Meta Quest 3. He can work out, play games, and explore an entirely new universe without leaving the living room. $199.99 If he's a music lover, treat him to a new turntable. He can spin his favorite tracks, and your space instantly gets a chic refresh. Bonus: In my experience, it makes future gifting way easier — just keep getting him vinyl of his most-played albums and call it a day. $887.00 $937.00 5% off For the true cinephile, turn your home into his private movie theater with this Sonos surround sound set. It's sleek, comes with a sub and two additional speakers, according to the brand, basically making every film feel like a premiere, without the overpriced popcorn. $279.99 $399.99 30% off You love him, but that doesn't mean you love his podcast choices (or hearing Instagram reels over and over again). Get him these Sony headphones — powerful, comfortable, and some of our top-rated cans — so he can enjoy his deep-dive commentaries without dragging you along for the ride. $18.00 If he's the Jim to your Pam, or the Michael Scott to your Holly Flax, get him this New York Times bestselling book by Andy Greene. It's a deep, delightful dive into the show that has basically become a third member of our household (and I'm guessing yours). $2,895.00 $3,295.00 12% off Remember that infamous Peloton Christmas commercial? While the internet was mad, I still stand by this: a Peloton is a great gift for anyone looking to ditch their gym membership or take fitness more seriously than “maybe I'll go work out today.” $50.00+ If your husband is a concert superfan or a die-hard sports guy, a live event is a holiday slam-dunk. Surprise him with tickets to an upcoming game or show in your area, and then obviously make him buy all the popcorn, drinks, and merch once you're there. It's basically a gift for you, too. $22.97 If sushi is as essential in your home as filtered water, get him this fun pair of chopsticks from Amazon. Whether he aligns with the Light Side or the Dark Side (for your sake, hopefully the Light), he'll appreciate the cheeky practicality. $754.00 If your husband is the chef in the family (and if he isn't, put that boy to work), he needs this Ooni electric pizza oven to level up. It's compact (ours lives right on the counter), makes pies even Anthony Mangieri would nod at approvingly, and best of all, it keeps him busy so you can finally watch your shows on the big screen in peace. $229.99 If he can name F1 drivers faster than he can name your closest friends, get him this F1 LEGO set. It's sleek enough that you won't mind it on display, and it's designed for ages 18+ (which, let's hope, he qualifies for). $120.00 If he likes to keep things spicy, go for the official Hot Ones box set. Ten sauces, ranging from “this is fine” to “what the f*** was that” — he can decide how hot he wants his night to get. $32.40 $54.00 40% off For a gift that he'll never grow tired of, get him this boudoir photo album. No need for a professional photographer, use a Polaroid, print instantly, and enjoy the results. Plus, you avoid the awkward possibility of a stranger seeing your bits on a studio monitor. This might honestly be one of the best gifts you ever give him. Trust me. $33.00+ If paying for cable is one of his favorite grievances, a Philo subscription might save both his wallet and your sanity. He'll get access to his beloved channels like History and A&E, and you won't have to hear about another price hike. $105.58 For the whiskey connoisseur, Suntory is the way to go. Slip it into his stocking and watch his Christmas get instantly merrier and blurrier (we mean brighter). $300.00 Sure, you may not love that he goes “all in” at poker night (if he bets his life savings, that's a separate conversation), but this monogrammed poker set will have him looking like the classiest guy at the table. Wood, velvet, and undeniably cooler than the flimsy internet version. $14.99 Sometimes husbands are a little reckless with their wedding rings — this is generalizing, sure, but you know I'm right. If you don't want him stressing about losing it on your upcoming vacation, get him these silicone bands as placeholders. The world will still know he belongs to you, without risking the real ring sinking and belonging to the bottom of the Caribbean. $54.99 Make his Yule log rise with this penis ring from Lovehoney. It's guaranteed to be fun for both of you for less than $60. $24.72 $30.00 18% off Sure, he might not make it to Oktoberfest every year like he dreams, but at least he can pretend he's there with this Stanley Stein. It's currently 18% off on Amazon and comes in multiple color — prost to that. $27.75 $37.00 25% off This is by far one of the coolest (and most appreciated) gifts I've ever given my husband. You choose his favorite song, send it to Etsy, and they turn it into soundwave art he can hang in his office or your media room. It's the perfect amount of sentimental while also doubling as chic home décor. $34.79 If your husband is anything like mine, his devotion to Star Wars is almost as serious as our wedding vows. Okay, that might be an exaggeration, but for the Jedi superfan, get him a printed script of A New Hope. Instant family heirloom, whether you've actually seen the movie or not. We want to hear it. Hilary Swank apologizes for lashing out at mom taking terminally ill sons on Make-A-Wish trip
Source: pagesix.com    Published: 2025-12-11 01:32:00

Hilary Swank has apologized after snapping at a mom for seemingly taking her picture at the airport without her permission. Jada Bafus, who was taking her two terminally ill sons, Mason, 7, and Jack, 4, on a trip to Disneyland, said she happened to spot the Oscar winner at Los Angeles' LAX airport during the Make-A-Wish trip. “At baggage claim, I was walking next to Hilary Swank,” Bafus said, according to the Daily Mail. “And I did a double take on her because it's Hilary Swank and I am a fan of her movies and stuff.” Bafus said she took out her phone “because I got distracted and trying to find my Make-A-Wish kids and my husband.” “I just looked, like you know, I was trying to call my husband. I wasn't taking a picture.”On social media, Bafus detailed that Swank said to her, “You got what you needed? Get what you came for? Enjoy that picture.” Bafus claimed that Swank “stormed off a little bit” following the encounter. “It just hurt my feelings because I was starting my son's Make-A-Wish trip, which she wouldn't have known, but just one of those situations where it was one of my first encounters with a celebrity so I thought it was a little comical,” Bafus said. “We just don't know what others are going through and I was just a stressed mom trying to navigate LAX.“ Bafus' sons are battling Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, a rare genetic disorder defined by extreme muscle weakness caused by progressive muscle degeneration. The condition is terminal and typically leads to loss of mobility by age 12 and a shortened lifespan. Bafus later noted that Swank reached out with an apology. Start your day with Page Six Daily. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want celebrity news as it breaks? She told the outlet that Swank reached out via Instagram to apologize, and explain she was worried about her twin toddlers, Aya and Ohm, being photographed. Bafus asked that the apology, which she shared with the outlet, not be reproduced. She expressed shock that Swank reached out. “I did not expect Hilary Swank to directly talk to me,” she said. “It was just like a ‘Woah, I was taken aback.'” Bafus' husband, Bryan, said the encounter was “unexpected at the start of our trip” and wondered why a two-time Oscar winner would be concerned about cameras. “To snap back at anybody when you're in that profession is kind of like ,,, I don't know — it is what it is,” he said, per the outlet, adding that the couple is “not upset” at Swank. A rep for the “Boys Don't Cry” actress did not immediately return Page Six's request for comment. Swank announced that she welcomed her twins with husband Philip Schneider in April 2023, and has never shared photos of their faces via social media. “I thought that it would be like this dream, but it's dreamier than I ever imagined,” she told Today of becoming a mom, in a February 2024 interview. “It blows open my whole world in the most beautiful way.”

No Funeral Planned for HGTV's Frank Cozzolino: His Daughter Explains Why
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-12-11 00:14:21

Thousands of HGTV fans have shared their condolences with the family and colleagues of Frank Cozzolino, who appeared for more than two decades on Mike Holmes' popular shows, including “Holmes on Homes” and “Holmes Family Rescue,” before his death at age 56 on December 4, 2025. Cozzolino's family and close friends are treasuring the memories from all who knew or knew of him rather than holding a funeral, according to the electrician's daughter, Filomena Cozzolino. In a social media post on December 6, she explained, “For all of those who'd like to pay their respects, he did not wish to have a funeral. Rather, he wanted people to focus on the great times they shared with him.” Filomena continued, “His life, and the lives of his loved ones, was enhanced by organ donation; we can take a moment to honour him by donating to organ transplant research, cancer research, or signing up for organ donation. This way, we may continue to bring others a second, or third, chance at life.” Cozzolino, a Canadian contractor who ran his own business in Toronto, Solutions Electrical & Maintenance, also became close friends with Holmes when he began appearing on his shows, beginning with the very first episode of “Holmes on Homes.” Cozzolino underwent a liver transplant in August 2017, which he wrote in an Instagram post felt like a “second chance at life.” His liver disease was an occasional topic on Holmes' shows, including an episode in which his team helped to renovate Cozzolino's home in 2022, according to Deadline. In her December 6 post, Filomena explained that his doctors had discovered his liver disease returned in early 2025 and that he became the “grateful recipient of a second transplant in July 2025.” She went on to say that “there were many post-operation complications, and he conquered each new battle, until he was diagnosed with lymphoma. Ever the fighter, he never gave up. He deliberated and decided that he would push through; he'd beaten the odds up to this point, he thought ‘the world isn't getting rid of me this easily.'” “Although he lost his battle in the late evening of December 4, 2025,” she continued, “my dad pushed the boundaries of what many of his medical team, friends, and family thought possible.” According to Cozzolino's obituary, he was survived by his longtime partner Lisa, and his two daughters, Filomena and Alexandria. Holmes considered him a dear friend and said in a post on December 9 that he was “devastated” to lose him. His kids and fellow HGTV co-stars, Mike Holmes Jr. and Sherry Holmes, also issued social media statements, expressing how much they'll miss Cozzolino. Sherry called him In a statement issued by HGTV on December 10, per Deadline, the network said, “We are deeply saddened to hear of Frank Cozzolino's passing. Frank was an exceptional craftsman whose kindness, integrity and unwavering dedication touched every project and every person he encountered.” Fans and friends have left tributes to Cozzolino across social media, including on Holmes' posts about him. One wrote on his YouTube video about the late electrician, “Omg ….. not Frank!….. heartbreaking news. I'm so sorry, Mike. I know he turned into a friend and then more like family over the years. He's the most honest electrician I've ever seen. Rip Frank.” “Holmes Family Rescue” is expected to return on HGTV in 2026; it's not clear if Cozzolino was able to film any episodes for the next season before his death. Comment Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment. Δ Previous Next Like EntertainmentNow? Japanese Breakfast's Michelle Zauner on Her ‘Materialists' Song, Favorite Rom-Coms, and Stalled ‘Crying in H Mart' Film
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-12-11 00:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. Celine Song‘s throwback-to-the-1990s romantic dramedy “Materialists” premiered way back at the top of summer 2025. (A different time, am I right?) But the A24 release, which stars Dakota Johnson as a matchmaker torn between working-class ex-boyfriend Chris Evans and suave finance bro Pedro Pascal, is back in the conversation thanks to the Oscar race. And specifically, it's vying for placement among the Best Original Song shortlist being announced next weekend, for Japanese Breakfast's “My Baby (Got Nothing at All).” As a refresher — with mild “Materialists” spoilers ahead — the song plays over the end credits as Lucy (Johnson) and John (Evans) tie the knot in Manhattan's city hall, in the same room where perfunctory marriages take place every day and also where Song and her husband, Justin Kuritzkes, had their nuptials. Depending on how empty or full the glass is feeling at that point, and whether you believe Lucy and John's relationship can survive their disparate views on money, you can read the film‘s final scene as hopeful or hopeless. And Japanese Breakfast's “My Baby,” penned by lead vocalist Michelle Zauner, is the perfect catchy bop to accompany that poetic ambiguity. Related Stories ‘The Mysterious Gaze of the Flamingo' Review: Chile's Oscar Submission Is a Tender Western Pastiche About the Origins of Hate ‘The Moment' Trailer: Charli XCX Skewers Brat Summer and Jokes About Cocaine in Sundance-Bound Satire Grammy-nominated East Coast-originated indie band Japanese Breakfast started spinning lovelorn tales in 2013. Since then, the Korean-born singer lead singer has lost her mom, married her boyfriend, and wrote a book about it all called “Crying in H Mart.” (A film adaptation set up at MGM is currently on pause, and now without the originally attached Will Sharpe as director.) She's also released four albums with Japanese Breakfast, including the band's latest, “For Melancholy Brunettes (& Sad Women).” Speaking to IndieWire, Zauner said that writing “My Baby” proved an upbeat catharsis compared to crafting the somber sounds that make up that 10-track album. Below, we discuss the writing process for “My Baby,” how Zauner's own romantic experiences connect to the movie, and the status of her “Crying in H Mart” movie. This interview has been edited for length. IndieWire: You and Celine Song are both millennials who aren't that many years apart, and both bring a Korean-American background to your work. Was “Materialists” your first meeting? Michelle Zauner: Surprisingly, we never met up until this movie collaboration happened. I was a fan, and I think she had heard of my music before…. We first met on Zoom, and then I don't think we met in person until after the song [“My Baby (Got Nothing at All)”] was recorded, and the movie was put together, and she came to a show of mine. [She was] one of those people that you get along with right away. I have, many occasions in my life, met people that are millennials and Korean and artists, and it doesn't always happen. Just because all those things align doesn't mean you'll necessarily vibe. So it was really nice getting to meet her, because I think she's so brilliant, and also such a warm and fun person to get to hang out with. Did you see the full script or a full cut of the movie before writing the song? The movie was pretty much done. I was sent a screener, and it was the first time that I've ever watched a screener or gotten to be a part of a film process in this way. [Celine] was looking for a song for the end credits, which I thought was especially appealing because it kind of gave you full reign. You didn't really have to squeeze into a moment, and you weren't really responsible for pushing a viewer to feel a specific way beyond this almost summarizing feeling. It felt like I had more freedom getting to be a part of the end credit song than, maybe, if I had to insert myself into a really intense moment. I got to watch the full movie, and I really loved it. I just thought it was so modern, and it was something that I felt like was really missing from the zeitgeist. I just felt like it encompassed a lot of things that I've been thinking about as a 30-year-old woman, watching my friends go on dates and rue the current landscape. You've been with the same person for over a decade. Does the long-term nature of your relationship color the way you look at this movie, or romantic comedies in general? I don't want to speak out of turn, but I married very young. I married when I was 25, and it was kind of a rush situation where my mom — I wrote about this in my book [“Crying at H Mart”] — was sick and was going to die. [My boyfriend and I] had been dating for about a year and a half … We threw together a wedding in three weeks, and my mom was there, and it was a really beautiful ceremony. I was always kind of like, “Oh, we'll just get divorced if it doesn't work out. It's not a big deal.” We've been married for 11 years, and [originally] neither one of us had jobs, really, or any kind of financial security. And later, I learned that Celine and her husband actually married quite young as well, and that was something I was thinking a lot about, because my friends who are in their 30s and dating now, the things that they look out for [are] very different than the things that I considered when I was that age. My husband lived in a warehouse with, like, six roommates and had no windows and slept on a mattress on the ground, and at the time, I was just like, “He's hot, and that's all that matters.” And it worked out, because I feel like we really grew up together, and the things that what would be red flags for me now are things that we kind of learned together. So I think that what Celine has to say about that kind of perspective — that this desire to not give up hope for falling in love [not be] something that's only for the wealthy class — we shouldn't be so pessimistic about it. Did you write this song from the perspective of Dakota Johnson's character? I'm thinking of myself in Lucy's position and her choice at the end of the film, and to me, the lyrics are this chorus of people giving her advice. “You should find someone who has a company.” “You should find someone who makes a living.” “You should find someone who makes some figures.” They're kind of cute ways of turning those pieces of advice on their head [and saying,] “My partner doesn't have these things, but he offers something else.” Is there anything here that feels like a remnant of past work, or even a shred of an idea that you put a pin in from the past? This song is in the running for the Best Original Song Oscar, and one of the requirements is that songs have to be written anew for the film. [The song] came in a really great time, where I was just gearing up for my album cycle — this current album cycle “For Melancholy Brunettes (& Sad Women)” — and I had just written all these really melancholic, ethereal, contemplative, somber songs. I was excited to write something a bit more upbeat, something that was like a classic love song and felt good, after being, like, a very serious, type A artist about my record and, in the same breath, [wanting] to make something that I felt was clever and timeless. The only thing that carried over was I was using a lot of open D tuning on the last record, and that maybe my guitar had already been in that tuning and made its way onto the song. I saw your Letterboxd four favorites. “Melancholia” was on there — not exactly a romantic comedy, but a personal favorite. What are your favorite romantic comedies or romantic dramedies? If I were to do four romantic comedies, which I would say is my favorite genre … I love all Nora Ephron movies, but “When Harry Met Sally” I've maybe seen, like, 5,000 times. I really want to have a “When Harry Met Sally” party where we have apple pie à la mode with strawberry ice cream on the side and Katz's Deli, and we all wear the white sweater that Billy Crystal wore and play charades. “Exorcist baby!” I recently rewatched “Pride and Prejudice” with [Matthew Macfadyen]. (Celine is operating in that realm, to me — like a modern Austen tale.) That movie is so well done. And obviously, Ang Lee's “Sense and Sensibility” is so great. And I love anything Julia Roberts. I love “Notting Hill”; it's one of the few romantic comedies that you see largely from the male point of view. And “My Best Friend's Wedding” I love, too. Do you play “My Baby” now as part of setlists unrelated to “Materialists” FYC performances? Yeah, we do. I actually really love it. I think that people like the song, so it's so fun to perform, and sits in a sweet spot in my register. I think, because there were not a ton of upbeat songs on [my recent] record, it's been fun to incorporate it into the sets. I'm really proud of what we made. It sounds like you spent a year writing a script for “Crying in H Mart,” an adaptation of your very personal memoir about watching your mother die. I'm sorry to hear the project is on hold, but did you learn anything about yourself or your own stamina in the process? I learned a lot about the industry that makes a lot of sense to me now. It was a tough project because it was so personal, and this industry requires so much collaboration in order to make something happen. It costs so much money, and there's so much process involved and so many people involved. You cannot make a movie on your own in any way. That was interesting for me to witness and was challenging in ways that I expected and didn't expect. Are you wanting it to move forward, or feeling like you can set it down for now? I'm optimistic about it happening someday. I'm not interested in rushing; it's such a precious, personal story that I'd rather not make a movie than [make] a bad movie. And I love everyone that is involved and was involved in [helping it get] as far as it got, and would love to do it with the same people. But we're not in the midst of making it right now. You're writing another book, though. I'm currently writing my second book. It's also a memoir; I think it may be my last memoir. It's about the year I spent last year in Korea, learning the Korean language and going to school and living abroad and documenting that time. By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

🚨 Annual Fundraiser: Exclusive Autographed Items from Our Archives
Source: Skeptic    Published: 2025-12-11 18:15:52

Dear Supporters of Science, Reason, and Skepticism, Over 30 years ago, Pat Linse and I founded Skeptic magazine and the Skeptics Society—starting in my garage with a shared mission to promote science, reason, and critical thinking. Though Pat passed away a few years ago, her legacy lives on in everything we do: our educational work in schools, colleges, and prisons; our media and outreach projects; Skeptic magazine; original research from the Skeptic Research Center; our podcasts; and our upcoming documentary film. None of this work is possible without supporters like you. This December, we're asking for your support.A donation to the Skeptics Society isn't just a contribution—it's an investment in research, education, and evidence-based understanding in an increasingly complex world. All donations are tax-deductible, so please consider giving before the end of the year. This year, we're offering a very limited number of rare archival items as an exclusive thank-you for your support. Available only through the button below: If you prefer to donate without selecting a gift or if all gifts are already claimed, visit skeptic.com/donate. Thank you for standing with us in support of science and reason. With gratitude,Michael ShermerExecutive Director, The Skeptics Societyand the entire Skeptic team Think a friend would enjoy this? Send it their way! Michael Shermer is the Editor-in-Chief of Skeptic magazine and the bestselling author of “Conspiracy," "Why People Believe Weird Things," and other books on science and skepticism. Paranormal fans invited to guided ghost tours at local historic Texas hospital
Source: crossroadstoday.com    Published: 2025-12-11 17:04:00

Victoria Resize: YORKTOWN, Texas - This weekend, paranormal enthusiasts will have a unique opportunity to investigate the historic Yorktown Memorial Hospital, a property known for its alleged hauntings and famously featured on TV shows like Ghost Adventures and Destination Fear, as well as popular YouTube channels including Sam and Colby and Amy's Crypt. The event offers a real paranormal experience, including a guided tour, a guided séance in the chapel, independent investigation time, expert assistance from seasoned paranormal investigators, access to investigation tools, reference materials, and complimentary snacks and water. Attendees can choose from three ticket options based on their interest and availability: VIP All-Night Pass: Limited to 16 guests, providing access from 7:30 PM to 4:00 AM with two guided séances. Early Investigation: From 7:30 PM to 11:00 PM, including a 10:00 PM séance with the Curious Twins, Fred Garza-Guzman. Late Investigation: From 11:30 PM to 4:00 AM, including a 3:00 AM séance also with the Curious Twins, Fred Garza-Guzman. The event will be held on Friday, Dec. 12, and Saturday, Dec. 13, at Yorktown Memorial Hospital, located at 728 W Main St, Yorktown, Texas. For questions or to purchase tickets by phone, interested indivuals can call or text 210-802-9187. Tickets are also available for secure purchase online through the official booking link. Erika Kirk has one word for Candace Owens, who's been peddling conspiracy theories about Charlie Kirk
Source: CBS News    Published: 2025-12-11 16:41:36

Watch CBS News December 11, 2025 / 11:41 AM EST / CBS News Erika Kirk has one word for Candace Owens, who has been peddling conspiracy theories about her late husband, Charlie Kirk: "Stop." In a town hall set to air Saturday at 8 p.m. ET, CBS News editor-in-chief Bari Weiss asked Charlie Kirk's widow what she wants to say to Owens and others who are making unfounded claims about his assassination: "Stop. That's it. That's all I have to say. Stop." Owens used to work for Turning Point USA, the conservative youth organization founded by Charlie Kirk. The two were generally considered friends, with Owens describing their relationship as akin to that of a "brother and sister." A day after his assassination in September, she posted a nearly 25-minute video, saying she wanted him to be remembered for his career and ideas. But in the months since, Owens has pushed conspiracy theories about his murder and made unfounded fraud allegations about the finances at Turning Point, which Erika Kirk now runs. The Treasury Department sent Erika Kirk a letter last week, confirming that none of the tax-exempt entities she oversees are under investigation by the IRS. "The IRS is able to provide this type of information upon request by the taxpayer. And in this case, it's hideous that malicious lies and smears obligated [Erika Kirk] to make the request," a senior Treasury official told CBS News. Erika Kirk talks more about her husband, her journey through faith and grief, and the state of the American right in a CBS News town hall. It will air just days after Charlie Kirk's book, "Stop, in the Name of God: Why Honoring the Sabbath Will Transform Your Life," was posthumously released. Watch the one-hour town hall Saturday at 8 p.m. ET/CT on CBS. An extended version of the conversation will air on CBS News 24/7 on Sunday at 9 a.m., 3 p.m., 8 p.m. and 11 p.m. ET, and will be available on CBS News' YouTube channel. © 2025 CBS Interactive Inc. All Rights Reserved. (00:36) Copyright ©2025 CBS Interactive Inc. All rights reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


A different 'cold case': Frozen solid, she was nearly declared dead. Then, she was given a chance to live
Source: InForum    Published: 2025-12-11 15:42:00

Sponsored By ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISEMENT LENGBY, Minn. — Wally Nelson opened his front door on the morning of Dec. 20, 1990 and saw a 19-year-old woman lying in the snow, just feet from his home. “Her face was ghost-like,” Nelson told The Associated Press in 1990. “I figured she was dead.” ADVERTISEMENT Nelson recognized the young woman: Jean Hilliard, a family friend. Unbeknownst to Nelson, her vehicle veered into the ditch, miles away. "I had my parents' car, and I was just upset that I'd slid off the road," Hilliard, who now goes by Jean Vig, told Forum News Service. "I was hoping the car was okay. So even that night, the cold didn't really bother me or make me afraid. I was frustrated more than anything." A cold snap had hit Minnesota that evening, with temperatures dipping below 22 degrees Fahrenheit, according to newspaper accounts from the time. Vig knew she was close to the Nelson home, which belonged to family friend. So, in the frigid Minnesota night, she attempted the trek to his house. "I knew he lived down the road and had a pickup truck, so he could pull me out," Vig said. Yet as Vig set off on foot — dressed in cowboy boots, jeans and a snowmobile jacket — she began to realize Nelson's home was farther away than she anticipated. "It was a little country road, and there were little hills. So I'd get over a little hill thinking his place was going to be there, and then I'd get there and it wouldn't be." ADVERTISEMENT She kept going — and she nearly made it. "The last thing I remember was being at the top of the hill and seeing his house," Vig said. Tracks in the snow told the rest of the story. “You could see where she had crawled the last few feet before collapsing,” Nelson told the Associated Press. “You could also see where she had fallen three or four times from the mailbox, one-eighth of a mile down the road.” The tracks kept going, indicating she crawled across his yard and up onto his doorstop, where she collapsed. She spent roughly six to seven hours passed out in the below zero temperatures. Hilliard's body was frozen stiff when Nelson picked her up and placed her — diagonally — in the backseat of his car that morning. ADVERTISEMENT He raced to the hospital, hoping for a miracle. When they arrived at the hospital, her temperature didn't register on a standard medical thermometer. They couldn't find a pulse. Medical staff also weren't able to insert any needles as her skin remained frozen. Her eyes weren't responding to light, either. They would have considered her deceased — if they hadn't heard the faint gurgling sounds that resembled a form of breathing. "They couldn't get a pulse right away, but then they heard a gurgle like through my nose and determined that I was somehow breathing," Vig said. Hospital staff wrapped Hilliard's body with water-based heating pads. Within two to three hours, she began to respond to treatment. Hilliard wasn't in the clear, though. Her breaths per minute — one to two — were far below the normal rate of 12 to 20 per minute. As the day progressed, she gradually began to wake up. By that afternoon, her cognitive ability was back to normal. ADVERTISEMENT When awake, Vig could see the black blisters on her toes. It was a concerning sign for her medical team. Amputation was a possible scenario. Yet as Vig later learned, just hours before she was fully awake, her doctors informed her family that if she did make it, she could have to have both legs amputated, too. At the time the family was told this, her legs were showing signs of detrimental frostbite. Just as her legs regained their fleshy tone and normal function, her toes cleared up as well. She walked away from the near-death experience without any long-term side effects. Life for the 19-year-old was different when she was discharged from the hospital. "I got calls from reporters and from magazines, so it didn't really go back to normal for quite some time." ADVERTISEMENT It didn't take long for her story to spread throughout the country. Newspapers from Fargo to California carried the story, with headlines that read, “Woman survives six-hour exposure to sub-zero weather” and “Woman comes to life from out of the cold.” Her recovery was considered a medical mystery — and miracle. “I can't explain why she's alive. She was frozen stiff, literally,” her physician, Dr. George Sather, M.D. told the Associated Press. “It's a miracle.” Vig doesn't disagree. Just as news coverage reached all corners of the country, Vig learned that she had been at the center of many prayer group and churches, who took an active interest in her recovery. "I do think it was a miracle," she said. "I found out later just how far the prayer chain spread. So, I had a lot of people praying for me." She isn't certain why her life was spared, and she's content with not knowing or understanding. ADVERTISEMENT "It's not something I really dwell on. I mean it could be something as simple as my kids or my grandkids ... something special in their life." Vig went on to live a relatively normal life. She had three daughters, who she raised on a farm before moving to the northern suburbs of the Twin Cities in the mid-1990s. It was during that time when her story resurfaced. In 1996, her story was featured on Unsolved Mysteries. At the time, the television show was among the most popular in the nation. Vig was happy with the way the television show portrayed her story. And just as it was when she was 19 years old, people began to show interest in her story. Vig is happy to answer questions and share her experiences — especially around Christmas. "It happened just before Christmas. So that was Dec. 20," Vig said. "People are looking for miracles and the good that has happened." There are a few questions Vig commonly fields regarding her survival, one of which addresses any possible health issues she has from her time as a human ice cube. The only thing she cant think of? She now prefers cold weather over the heat. "I can tolerate the cold better than than the heat," she said. "So, I'm not I'm not one of those that wants to go to Florida or Arizona in the winter." ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISEMENT
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Microlensing Signatures Of Dyson Sphere-like Structures Around Primordial Black Holes As Technosignatures Of Extraterrestrial Advanced Civilizations
Source: astrobiology.com    Published: 2025-12-11 14:56:38

We investigate the microlensing detectability of extraterrestrial technosignatures originating from Dyson sphere – like structures, such as Dyson Swarms surrounding primordial black holes (PBHs). These hypothetical swarms consist of stochastically varying, partially opaque structures that could modulate standard microlensing light curves through time-dependent transmission effects. We introduce a probabilistic framework that includes a stochastic transmission model governed by variable optical depth and random gap distributions. We perform a parameter scan and generate heatmaps of the optical transit duration. We study the infrared excess radiation and peak emission wavelength as complementary observational signatures. Additionally, we define and analyze the effective optical depth and the anomalous microlensing event rate for these stochastic structures. Our findings provide a new avenue for searching for extraterrestrial advanced civilizations by extending microlensing studies to include artificial, dynamic modulation signatures. Shant Baghram Comments: 9 pages, 7 figures, 1 table. Accepted for publication in the Astrophysical JournalSubjects: Instrumentation and Methods for Astrophysics (astro-ph.IM); Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics (astro-ph.CO); Earth and Planetary Astrophysics (astro-ph.EP); Popular Physics (physics.pop-ph)Cite as: arXiv:2512.07924 [astro-ph.IM] (or arXiv:2512.07924v1 [astro-ph.IM] for this version)https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2512.07924Focus to learn moreSubmission historyFrom: Shant Baghram[v1] Mon, 8 Dec 2025 18:50:48 UTC (462 KB)https://arxiv.org/abs/2512.07924Astrobiology, SETI, Technosignature, AStronomy, Explorers Club Fellow, ex-NASA Space Station Payload manager/space biologist, Away Teams, Journalist, Lapsed climber, Synaesthete, Na'Vi-Jedi-Freman-Buddhist-mix, ASL, Devon Island and Everest Base Camp veteran, (he/him) 🖖🏻 2025 © Reston Communications. All rights reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Unseen Frequencies: A Deep Dive into the Paranormal World of JuXinaaa The Hype Magazine: Unveiling the Pulse of Urban Culture
Source: The Hype Magazine    Published: 2025-12-11 09:18:41

In the vast landscape of Twitch, where gaming, reaction content, and livestream entertainment shape the digital world, there is one creator whose presence stands apart: Giuseppa Salinas Gomez Gomez, better known as JuXinaaa or La Madrina. With a life marked by intuition, spiritual sensitivity, and profound personal experiences, she has built a unique space where the paranormal, the mysterious, and the deeply emotional intertwine with humor, community, and curiosity. Her streams invite viewers into an atmosphere that feels both intimate and electric — a place where energy is analyzed as closely as evidence, where intuition is treated as a compass, and where science and the supernatural sit at the same table. Together with her devoted community, the “Kiddos,” Juxinaaa explores paranormal videos, documentaries, investigations, and experiments, reacting not just with commentary but with a sensitivity shaped by her own real-life encounters. In this exclusive interview, she shares her origins, her spiritual lineage, the night that changed everything, and how she brings authenticity into a world where belief and skepticism collide. 1. How did you first come into contact with the paranormal, and what motivated you to turn it into Twitch content? I grew up around the paranormal. In my family, there were several tragic events — including murders — and every time, someone would feel this deep intuition that something was about to happen. I was raised with that energy. My Spanish grandmother was very spiritual, and when I was little, I actually thought she was talking to me in dreams. Later I realized they weren't dreams at all — they were real conversations, warnings, and energies. That intuitive ability runs in my family, and I've carried it with me my whole life. Twitch eventually became the place where all of that could come together — the stories, the mystery, the humor, and the spiritual side. 2. What criteria do you use to decide which videos or cases you react to on stream? Authenticity and energy are everything to me. I look at: • the vibe of the video • the atmosphere • whether the emotions feel real • and the resonance it has with me and my community. If something feels energetically genuine, I'll react to it. If not, I'll usually skip it. 3. Was there a paranormal experience in your own life that strongly shaped how you see all of this? Yes — the night my friend was murdered. On the morning of the day it happened, I had this deep, unsettling feeling in my stomach. It wasn't fear, just a knowing. Later that day, we were at his parents' house, and suddenly men broke in. We escaped onto the roof. I had a package with me that he asked me to leave behind, but my intuition said, “Take it.” I still don't know exactly what was inside — but my gut told me it mattered. Maybe it protected others. Maybe it changed something. But I couldn't save him. That moment defined my relationship with intuition forever. And the night he died, I felt our connection snap before I was told anything. That sudden energetic shift is the foundation of my spiritual worldview. 4. How do you handle it when scientific explanations and supernatural interpretations collide in your community? For me, science and the supernatural aren't enemies. Science explains a lot — but not everything. I keep both sides open, neutral, and even humorous. My streams are a dialogue: I show scientific reasoning respect, but I also acknowledge the experiences that don't fit into that box. 5. What's the most surprising or disturbing investigation you've ever reacted to on stream? Some investigations shake people because of the atmosphere — strange sounds, sudden shifts in energy, or visuals that just don't sit right. My community often picks up on details immediately. For me, it's rarely fear — but sometimes a case has a heaviness that even I can't ignore. Those moments stay with me. 6. Do you ever experiment with occult methods or paranormal tests live on stream? If so, what have your experiences been like? I don't experience fear the way most people do. I don't believe in fear — I believe in perception. When I experiment with energetic or spiritual methods on stream, I stay very calm, clear, and grounded. If something happens in the room or the energy shifts, I register it, but without panic. Some moments have been intense for viewers, though — certain sounds or atmospheres can feel unsettling to the community, even if I'm completely steady. 7. How do you evaluate the authenticity of paranormal clips? Do you have any red flags or analysis techniques? Definitely. Some of my biggest red flags are: • shadows that make no sense, • timing that's off, • atmospheric inconsistencies, • lack of real emotional response, • and energy that simply feels wrong or forced. I react only to clips that feel energetically real. 8. How does your community influence the flow of your streams, especially when it comes to spontaneous reactions and interpretations? My community — my Kiddos — is a real part of my intuitive process. They notice tiny details, they catch things I might miss, and together we break down the energy of a moment. It's a shared experience. Their input shapes the direction of the stream constantl 9. Has there ever been a moment during a stream when you were truly scared or something unexplainable happened? I wouldn't say I've ever been truly scared. Fear isn't something I operate with. But yes — there have been moments when something shifted suddenly, energetically, and everyone felt it at the same time. Those experiences weren't frightening for me, but they were definitely powerful. 10. What future projects or paranormal topics do you want to explore more deeply on Twitch? There's so much left to uncover — deeper analyses, new investigations, more spiritual experiments, and exploring the line between intuition and energy on an even higher level. My goal is always the same: to bring my community with me into these experiences so we can explore the unknown together. www.thehypemagazine.com. ... [Trackback] [...] Here you will find 4922 additional Inf... ... [Trackback] [...] Info on that Topic: thehypemagazine.co... ... [Trackback] [...] Info to that Topic: thehypemagazine.co... ... [Trackback] [...] Here you can find 64831 more Informati... ... [Trackback] [...] Here you will find 64433 more Informat...
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


This Classic Supernatural Episode Is the Scariest 44 Minutes of Winchester Lore
Source: Comic Book Resources    Published: 2025-12-11 09:00:00

"Saving people, hunting things, the family business" is a quote that has become synonymous with Supernatural, but no other season encapsulates this feeling like Season 1 of Supernatural does. Before the horror show fell into overarching storylines that lasted seasons, it was known for its snappy monster-of-the-week format, where Sam and Dean Winchester hunted down a different demon in every episode and actually saved countless lives while doing so. 20 years after the release of the first season, it remains the most iconic outing of the CW show. While the Winchesters were tracking down paranormal absurdities across the country, they were also rebuilding a bond that they had lost for many years. In Season 1, Episode 5, "Bloody Mary," Supernatural was at its finest, terrifying viewers with a familiar monster, while also giving them much-needed emotional payoff. The legend of Bloody Mary is one that has been worn thin over the past few decades, especially through email forwards that simplify it to the point where it ceases to be scary. According to the lore, if one faces a mirror and says "Bloody Mary" thrice, a woman will kill them instantly through the reflective surface. Supernatural decided to add layers to this old horror story, and the result was 44 minutes of pure terror. The episode begins as the scariest stories do: at a slumber party where three teen girls are playing sleepover games. Charlie and Jill dare Lilly to go to the bathroom mirror and say "Bloody Mary," which she does, but nothing happens. Lilly's father, Steven, asks the girls to keep the noise down, but when he goes back to his bedroom, he's haunted by a horrific figure in the mirror. With his eyes liquefied and his head filled with blood, Steven dies a sudden and agonizing death. As Sam and Dean descend on Toledo, Ohio, for another monster-of-the-week case, Jill decides to repeat the phrase "Bloody Mary" jokingly into a mirror, and soon sees the same dark figure and suffers the same agonizing death as Steven. Trying to find a pattern, Sam and Dean inspect the mirrors that the two victims died in front of, and found the names of Steven's wife and a little boy who had died in a hit-and-run case, whose car details matched Jill's. Sam and Dean find a vengeful spirit named Mary Worthington, who had been killed in front of a large mirror when she was a teenager, and when her murder was not solved, she started attacking those whom she thought had secretly killed other people, the way she had been. The mirror found its way to Toledo, and the brothers then worked towards saving Charlie, who was being followed by Mary because she once had a boyfriend who died by suicide when she left him. Finally, the brothers made Mary face herself in a mirror for the crimes she had committed, which led to the spirit finally dying. Supernatural could have taken the easy route and had Mary kill the people who summoned her, but writers Eric Kripke, Ron Milbauer, and Terri Hughes Burton chose to add layers to a story that had been done to death. They refreshed it by giving Mary an origin story; she used to be a young girl whose life was ended in an untimely manner. So, she made it her afterlife's purpose to avenge those who had killed people and gotten away with it. Mary Worthington's crusade for justice matched Sam Winchester's own guilt about his girlfriend, Jessica's death. Jessica had died in the same way his mother had, and Sam felt responsible because he had dreamed about her death for weeks, but had done nothing to prevent it. Throughout "Bloody Mary," Dean tried to get Sam to talk to him about the nightmares he was having, and to relieve him of his guilt because he could not have prevented Jessica's death in any way, but the show decided to tackle it through the monster of the week instead. Mary Worthington's spirit tried to attack Sam, and he, too, bled from his eyes, but the key lay in Sam finally trusting himself and his brother that he did not kill anyone. This horror masterpiece of a Supernatural episode had viewers jumping at every turn, but it also had the sweet sentimentality that formed the bedrock of the show. Sam had to process his grief and guilt about Jessica's death, and this lethal spirit helped to do just that, eventually drawing Dean and Sam closer than ever before. We want to hear from you! Share your opinions in the thread below and remember to keep it respectful. Your comment has not been saved This thread is open for discussion. Be the first to post your thoughts.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Alien Contact Tour brings extraterrestrial encounters to St. George
Source: St. George News    Published: 2025-12-11 03:30:00

Reporter St. George might see some out-of-this-world visitors this Sunday as aliens are set to make an appearance at Pioneer Park. “If you like the vision of universal peace, universal love and universal well-being, then you are going to enjoy this event,” said Alien Contact event coordinator and founder Rupert Guy. “It is all about trying to make the world a better place and trying to live in harmony with all conscious beings throughout the universe.” Guy said the Alien Contact event will begin with humans making friends before any extraterrestrial introductions. Although the main program starts at 7 p.m., guests can arrive at 6 p.m. to mingle in a friendly orbit. Guy said the goal is to bring people together in friendship regardless of differences, including religious beliefs or political convictions. The evening will move into a guided astral projection meditation designed to help participants reach out to any visiting beings and offer an open invitation for contact. Attendees at the Alien Contact event gather in hopes of encountering extraterrestrial beings, location and date not specified. “What typically happens is people start feeling the presence of these beings around us on the ground,” he said. “Psychic people will see them standing around trying to support what we are doing. Occasionally, we will see alien craft in the sky flying above us.” St. George is one stop on what Guy said will be a more than five-month Alien Friendship Contact Tour across the country. The tour began Nov. 30 in Bakersfield, California, and is scheduled to continue through Fresno and Sacramento before making six stops in Nevada, including Area 51. After St. George, the route moves to Page, then travels through New Mexico, Oklahoma, Missouri, Indianapolis, Kentucky, Tennessee, Georgia and Alabama, with a tentative finale planned in Arkansas. He planned the tour to cover as much of the United States as possible, estimating it would span 40-45 states. St. George naturally fit into the route between Sedona, Area 51 and other locations he considers key stops on the journey. A possible extraterrestrial craft is captured over an Alien Contact gathering, location and date not specified. Cosmic encounters At the first two events of his 2025 tour, Guy said attendees reported seeing black streaks darting through the air nearby. Around the same time, a member of his online group described receiving a “download” from alien beings and began noticing similar black streaks in her vision. Intrigued by the phenomenon, Guy attempted to connect with the streaks to discover who or what they might be. “We always reach out to beings with love in our hearts and friendly intentions,” he said. “It turned out that these black streaks identified themselves as positive, friendly beings who had a message for us.” Guy said that when participants communicated telepathically with the beings and asked for a message, three people in three different locations reported the same vision: Guy standing in a forest clearing, surrounded by a large group of nonhuman beings. He said the consistency of the visions across separate observers serves as logical proof of a genuine psychic telepathic message. He said he does not know when or where the vision will manifest, but it seems to serve as a notification or invitation to the forest clearing gathering. He hopes the meeting will take place during his tour. Rupert Guy, founder of Alien Contact, leads a U.S. tour designed to help humans connect with each other and extraterrestrial beings, location and date not specified. Guy said everyone can experience paranormal or alien encounters, but an open mind is key. The beings cannot force contact and will retreat if someone is not ready, though they can telepathically and empathically sense a person's mind and heart. How the cosmos called Growing up in England, Guy said he realized at an early age that he was more empathetic than most. He cared so deeply for people, animals and the planet that he could not watch the news because it was too painful. Determined to make a difference, he felt he first needed to understand reality. If God were real, he wanted God on his side. If aliens were real, he wanted them on his side or anyone working to protect the planet. He began exploring aliens, paranormal phenomena and religions alongside scientific study. He attended the University of Leicester in England, earning a first-class honors degree in Physics with Space Science and Technology and later pursued advanced work in astrophysics and research. “I ended up with a pretty clear picture of scientific realities, but also alien, paranormal and spiritual realities,” he said. “I now teach people about these realities and try to elevate people's understanding of reality, but also morality to alien levels.” Rupert Guy, founder of Alien Contact, leads a U.S. tour designed to help humans connect with each other and extraterrestrial beings, location and date not specified. Guy is a retired space scientist and science teacher who calls California home but travels the world. He founded the group Alien Contact five years ago and has led about 10 tours since then. This is his first time hosting an event in St. George. “I have spent my entire life reaching out to aliens and spirits in peace, trying to establish friendly, constructive relationships with them,” he said. Join the Alien Contact event at Pioneer Park on Sunday, Dec. 14, from 7-9 p.m. Early birds can arrive at 6 p.m. to mingle in a friendship circle before the cosmic adventure begins. Dress warmly and bring a yoga mat or tarp to sit or lie on. Be ready for a short walk from the parking area to the contact spot, where the night's extraterrestrial encounters will unfold. For more details and tickets, visit the event page and prepare for a night that's truly out of this world. Reporter Success! An email has been sent to with a link to confirm list signup. Error! There was an error processing your request. Each day's obituaries, delivered to your inbox. Get the latest headlines on local sports!
